awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Functional morphology of a high-efficiency filtration mechanism identified in manta rays
awd_abstract_narration:
Mantas and devil rays are large fishes that feed by engulfing massive volumes of seawater, extracting plankton with a specialized filter structure, and expelling filtered water through the gill slits. These animals utilize a highly-efficient filtration mechanism, ricochet separation, that is distinct from previously-described biological or industrial filtration processes. This project will use a multidisciplinary approach to examine the fluid dynamics and filtration mechanics of this unique system. This project will characterize the anatomy of the filtering structure, identify how the shape of the structure affects the flow around the filter, and determine how the resulting flow patterns affect particle filtration. This work will provide critical insights into the physiology of an ecologically important and threatened group of animals. In addition, there is substantial need for improved filtering strategies for use in applications ranging from mitigating large-scale environmental contamination events to routine wastewater treatment. This project will elucidate the mechanics of a novel and highly-efficient filtration process, and has considerable potential to lead to advanced, bioinspired filtration systems. This research will also provide valuable training for undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral scientists and support activities to engage school-aged students and expose them to biomechanics and bioinspired engineering.


The filtering apparatus of mobulid fishes (mantas and devil rays) is a highly-specialized gill-raker structure. It has long been believed that the raker functioned as a sieve filter, simply trapping particles larger than the pore size. However, recent work has shown that the raker utilizes a unique filtration mechanism, ricochet separation, in which complex flow fields cause plankton particles to recoil off the filter surfaces and become concentrated within the buccal cavity. This filtration process has several favorable properties including that it efficiently separates particles smaller than the pore size, is highly resistant to clogging, and has low hydrodynamic resistance. This project will examine the fluid dynamic processes underlying this mechanism and the morphological factors that influence its performance. This research uses a multipronged approach that includes anatomical studies (micro computed tomography), experimental fluid mechanics (particle image velocimetry and filtration efficiency measurements), and theoretical modeling (computational fluid dynamics). Aim 1 will investigate the small-scale physical processes at the surface of the filter, identifying how individual plankton particles interact with the filter and how this interaction is affected by the morphology of the filter. Aim 2 will examine the large-scale flow patterns that develop in the mouth and will determine how this flow influences the filtration mechanics. Aim 3 will use an understanding of these processes to create and optimize bio-inspired engineered filtration systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Mobulid fishes (mantas and devil rays) are large fishes (up to 6m) that feed by continuously filtering plankton from seawater using a highly specialized gill-raker structure. It was believed that the gill raker functioned as a sieve filter, trapping particles larger than the pore size. However, recent work showed that the raker uses a unique filtration mechanism, where complex flow fields caused plankton particles to bounce off the filter surfaces and become concentrated within the buccal cavity (at the esophagus). We termed this “ricochet filtration”. This filtration process is substantially different from simple sieves or cross-flow filters currently used in the filtration industry. For example, it efficiently separates particles smaller than the pore size of the filter, is highly resistant to clogging, and operates at low pressures. However, questions remained about how these filters operate including how changes to the filter morphology influence the filtration efficiency and surrounding flow patterns. This project addressed these remaining questions by using physical and computational modeling to examine the flow fields around and filtering properties of mobulid filters by systematically varying the morphological parameters. We found that unlike in sieve-type or cross-flow filters, mantas use captive vortices that grow or shrink to fill the size of the filter pore; however, changes in vortex size produces only modest changes to the filtration efficiencies. The filtration efficiency appears to be highly sensitive to the shape and orientation of the filter lobes (microscale plate-like structures). These results provide a foundation for designing and optimizing bioinspired filtration devices and provides a roadmap for interpreting the morphological differences between species.

 

Intellectual Merit

The work performed on this project systematically examined the functional morphology and fluid dynamics of a novel filtering mechanism recently described in the filter-feeding apparatus of manta rays. We investigated the filtration mechanics at small size scales, to determine how individual plankton particles interacted with the filter and how this interaction was shaped by the morphology of the filter. We examined the complex, large-scale flow patterns within the buccal cavity and determined how these flow fields influence the filtration process. Finally, we tested a range of morphological parameters (realistic to mantas and outside the range of filters found in nature) to create optimized, bioinspired, engineered filtration systems. This work substantially advanced our understanding of a novel mode of filter feeding and yielded generalizable insights into the biomechanics of filter-feeding in large animals. Lessons learned were applied to additional large-scale biological systems (e.g. whales) and the filtration principles uncovered can be applied to engineered high-efficiency filtration systems. (See results from 2019 and 2020 Global design challenges).

 

Broader Impacts

Contributions to Basic Science: The work performed on this project provides critical insights into the physiology of an ecologically important and threatened group of organisms. In addition, there is substantial demand within the engineering community for improved filtering strategies for use in applications ranging from managing large-scale environmental contamination events to routine wastewater treatment. This work has considerable potential to lead to bioinspired, advanced filtration systems. In fact, there have been numerous groups who have based bioinspired filtration devices (microfluidic to large scale filtration) based off our work. 

Training and Mentoring: During this project we provided mentorship and training to undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers. The lead PI is located at a Hispanic serving institution and incorporated a diverse population of undergraduate and graduate students into her research group. The project provided new research opportunities for first generation and minority students, who received training in biomechanics, physiology, anatomy, and marine ecology. In addition, the research group actively engaged with the public through a wide range of media avenues (radio and television interviews, podcasts, newspaper articles, and public seminars).
